projects.title: Tallykeeper
projects.description: Tallykeeper is a scorekeeping app built with React, server-side Go code for its API, and a Postgres database. I settled on this project idea for its simplicity, since it allowed me to focus on learning key web development technologies: using Typescript with React, using Go for backend (I also just wanted to learn Go), using JWTs for authentication and persistent sessions, using Tailwind and making fully responsive UI's, multi-layered database dependencies (users -> lists -> list entries), and using Docker for both development and production. The end result is a simple but polished experience on desktop and mobile. From making this app, I've developed solid foundations in web technologies, and I'm prepared for much more featureful projects.

projects.title: Basic Notes
projects.description: Basic Notes introduced me to full-stack development by honing my frontend skills in React, my backend skills in Node.js, and introducing me to databases via Postgres. The app features a toggleable, sortable sidebar, full REST operations for all notes, autosaving, and a rudimentary login system. To prevent open access to user data, devices are provided with a secret user key on login which the backend requires for all operations on the user's data. Throughout the development, I became comfortable managing React's state and props, I learned how to make REST APIs, and I familiarized myself with full-stack architecture.

projects.title: ReVision
projects.description: ReVision was my team's submission for GateHacks 2025, Colgate University's annual hackathon. As a group of avid readers, we strived to reinvent the smartphone e-reader by making an attention-grabbing, smartphone-tailored experience. Our app boasts a full e-reader UI built on React Native, with a pixelated theme that fit our timeline. We focused on two features: automatic image generation, and reading summaries. We developed a Python script to split a text into chunks and prompt DALL-E, whose images were then inserted into the EPUB file. For reading summaries, we took the past ~500 words before the user's location in a book, and used ChatGPT's api. We ended up getting 2nd place at the hackathon. This project improved my ability to program with a team, and we plan to fully develop the app in the future.
